items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District has 3 pallets of computers and monitors (See attached Surplus Forms, 2 pages).  The District’s Educational Technology Services Department (ETS) staff has determined that the items are of no further use to the District.  In accordance with the Electronic Waste Recycling Act these items are considered electronic waste. The estimated aggregate market value of this electronic equipment is greater than $5,000.00.
	 
California Education Code 81450 provides the governing board of any community college district may sell for cash any personal property belonging to the district if the property is not required for school purposes, or if it should be disposed of for the purpose of replacement, or if it is unsatisfactory or not suitable for school use. The code requires the sale to be advertised at least once a week for two weeks. The board shall sell the property to the highest responsible bidder or reject all bids.
	 
Purchasing Services will advertise  at least once a week for two weeks in the San Jose Post Record and also post a notice on Bid Net to call for competitive bids from authorized State of California material handlers, collectors, and recyclers. Proceeds will be deposited to the District's general fund.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Interim Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize Gina Bailey, Interim Director of Purchasing Services to sell the items in accordance with Education Code 81450.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District owns surplus furniture that has been replaced with new (see attached lists, 11 pages).  It has been determined that the furniture is old and at the end of life or is in such poor condition that it is unusable.  District staff estimates the value of this furniture to be less than $100.00 in the aggregate.
	 
California Education Code 81452(c) provides that if the governing board, by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, is of insufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale, the property may be disposed of in the local public dump on order of any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board.
	 
District Staff will dismantle the items and recycle or dispose of the components appropriately.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Interim Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the items are of insufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale and authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services to recycle the items or dispose of them in the local public dump.
items.item_text: Recycle and Dispose of Surplus Furniture
items.item_text_raw: 4. Recycle and Dispose of Surplus Furniture

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
As required under Title-5 section 58301, the Board held a public hearing on the 2013-14 fiscal year budget at their meeting on August 26, 2013.  Vice Chancellor Kevin McElroy and Interim Budget Director Joni Hayes reviewed the budget document.  This was an informational presentation and no action was taken.  There were no changes made to the proposed budget at the August 26, 2013 meeting.  An electronic copy of the budget is posted on the district web site here:
	 
http://fhdafiles.fhda.edu/downloads/budget/1314AdoptedBudget.pdf
	 
Consistent with the requirements of Title 5 section 58305, which requires that on or before the 15th day of September, the governing board of each district shall adopt a final budget, we recommend that FHDA Board of Trustees adopt the 2013-14 budget as presented.  
	 
Submitted by:
  Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, ext. 6201
Additional contact names:
  Joni Hayes, Interim Budget Director, ext. 6261
Is backup provided?
  No
items.item_recommendation: Vice Chancellor of Business Services Kevin McElroy recommends adoption of the 2013-14 budget

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The De Anza College Advanced Technology Center (ATC) building renovation is complete and classes will be open for Winter Quarter classes in January 2014. De Anza staff and District staff are proceeding forward with several purchases of technology equipment, furniture, equipment and supplies to ensure a successful opening.  Several classroom labs within the ATC require computer tables that can also function as regular classroom desks.  The De Anza FF&E Coordinator worked to locate products that would fit that need. Product proposals from three potential manufacturers were considered: a proposal from KI, a proposal from Spectrum Industries, and a proposal from ISE, Inc.   After review of the table specifications required based upon function and the classroom layouts, KI determined that it would not be able to provide a viable solution. Spectrum and ISE each manufacture the tables that meet the campus need in a manual and electric version.  Both vendors also indicated they would modify the size of the tables to meet the spatial requirements of the classrooms while maintaining the desired seat count.  Samples of the tables were provided to the campus for testing.  
 
The De Anza College VP of Instruction and several Deans tested the functionality of the tables and discussed the pros and cons of the manual version versus the electric version. They concluded that the electric version of the tables was the best fit for the campus needs and the preferred choice was the Spectrum product.  Initially, Spectrum provided a quote for the electric tables however it later rescinded the quote and informed the District that a corporate decision had been made to no longer sell the electric version of the table because of its concerns regarding long-term performance of its product or any similar electric product.  Even though campus administration strongly preferred the electric version of the table, Spectrum’s concern regarding any electric version of the table prompted the campus to rethink the purchase of the electric version.  To clarify whether other vendors shared the concerns expressed by Spectrum, Purchasing Service staff contacted ISE regarding the performance of its electric table.  ISE confirmed in writing that it stood behind its product and would provide the District with a lifetime warranty on all electrical and moving parts.  Furthermore, Purchasing Staff and the De Anza FF&E Coordinator reached out to other public agencies in California who purchased the tables to verify the performance of tables in use.  As a result of this research, the De Anza administration continues to firmly believe that it is in the best interest of the District to purchase the ISE electronic version of the table.  
 
Public Contract Code (PCC) section 20652, often referred to as the "piggy back" statute, provides that community college districts may under certain conditions utilize contracts that have been awarded by other public entities when the governing board finds it to be in the best interest of the District.  To conduct a competitive bid at this time would take approximately 3 - 4 months to complete the bid and award process plus an additional 6-8 weeks to deliver the product upon receipt of a Purchase Order.  Therefore, Purchasing Staff recently worked with ISE and its local dealer, Pivot Interiors, Inc. to determine if there were any competitively bid state or national contracts that it could take advantage of pursuant to PCC 20652 while leveraging the most advantageous pricing from such contract.  ISE and Pivot prepared a price quote for the purchase of the electric tables based off of a contract that is administered by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.  Accomplishing our due diligence on this potential purchase involved obtaining factual confirmations that those conditions for use of PCC section 20652 do exist. District legal counsel, Mr. John Shupe of Lynch and Shupe, LLP also reviewed the information for contract validity for California community colleges and provided guidance in our due diligence efforts.  Because of the quirky language of PCC Section 20652, there is always a risk when a community college district makes its piggyback purchase directly with the vendor rather than through the public agency that obtained the favorable pricing structure. Mr. Shupe is satisfied that the risks associated with the purchase contracts we are proposing are minimal and acceptable. We have investigated and confirmed the following. First, the price proposal from ISE is piggybacked off of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Department of General Services (Commonwealth) contract #4400009429. That contract also allows for contracted items to be reconfigured (modified to fit the special requirements). Second, we have learned that this Commonwealth contract contains a clause explicitly providing that other public entities can piggyback upon its pricing structure. Third, our investigation revealed that the Commonwealth contract with ISE was entered into after a valid, competitive bid process. Fourth, the contract states that all purchase orders and invoicing/payments will be made directly to the contractor of record (ISE). Fifth, while the contract does include a small service (installation) component, which if let separately might be within a bid requirement, in counsel's view that component is related enough and small enough that it is acceptable to include it in this piggyback purchase.
 
The total cost of this procurement is $287,279.14 and will be funded through Measure C FF&E. A copy of the ISE/Pivot quote #135546.002 is attached.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Interim Director, Purchasing Services, x6165
Additional contact names:
Donna Jones-Dulin x8209, Dawn Allshouse x6162
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: To satisfy PCC section 20652, Gina Bailey, Interim Director of Purchasing Services, recommends the Board of Trustees make a finding that it is in the best interests of the District to purchase computer tables directly from ISE, Inc. in the amount of $287,279.14 based upon the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania contract #4400009429, and authorize the purchase.
items.item_text: Purchase of ISE, Inc. computer tables for the ATC Building at De Anza College - $287,279
items.item_text_raw: C) Purchase of ISE, Inc. computer tables for the ATC Building at De Anza College - $287,279
